div.head: GORKI AND THE RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
div.p: Gorki, the Russian novelist, whose life is an epitome of Russian social conditions, has a three-column letter in the "Nation" of June 22, on "England and the Russian Revolution."

"You ask for my opinion concerning the intended entente cordiale with Russia and the desire of the Russian Government to borrow money in England ; you also wish to know what I consider would be the effect of such an entente on civilisation in Russia.

"I should like you to consider," says Gorki, "these questions from the point of view of men who are convinced that human reason will finally triumph over animal instinct, still far too powerful in contemporary European society. That point of view cannot surely be foreign and incomprehensible to England, a nation of an ancient civilisation, and to Englishmen so proud of their love of justice.

"The position in Russia to-day is as follows : your future ally, oh ! you English, you who are so proud of your ancient civilisation, is drenched from head to foot in the blood of the Russian people. He is struggling with all his might, and without discrimination, to attain complete autocratic power, and to uphold a form of government which has clearly grown old. Spiritual and economic progress are at a standstill in the land. The autocratic form of government is only useful and convenient to the Tsar, because it gives him unlimited power, and to the bureaucracy, because it enables them to rob without limit and without control.

"The people have very little education, but they begin to understand the value of knowledge, and are greedy for it. The people are struggling for freedom to learn ; the Tsar for freedom to rule, and the bureaucracy for freedom to steal. The womout, the old, and the sick are contending with the young, who promise to invest their all in the peaceful treasury of mind and spirit. The struggle is of general European importance. If the Government temporarily conquers, a hearth will exist at your doors round which all sorts of catastrophes will gather, the moral influence of which will undoubtedly be hurtful to the development of civilisation in Europe.

"Britons, you have a choice to make. Will you support the tyrant with his satellites and their anti-civilising plans, or will you support the growing young democracy, capable of life and rich in the strength of its spirit?

"The struggle will undoubtedly last long, and will end either in the formation of a great Russian democracy, or in the complete ruin of Russia as a political entity. I am, of course, aware that the cause of the people will not be espoused ; such a thing, it seems, has not yet occurred in history, and is not likely to occur. Indeed, Governments help each other to keep the people in subjection.

"But right will triumph in the end. I myself believe in the victory of justice ; I believe in the power of the Russian people ; and Russia will, I think, either become the best democracy in Europe, or she will crumble and break in pieces, like unhappy Poland.
"But I hear you exclaim : 'You have your Duma ; you have a constitution, it is now surely possible to attain your ends by legitimate means.'

"It seems to me hardly worth while to talk seriously about this. In the first place, the Duma is crippled, feeble, and powerless, and will undoubtedly be soon dissolved. When the Emperor a few weeks ago received a deputation of the Black Hundred, he said to one of the delegates who had earned an uneviable reputation for himself on account of his indiscreet behaviour in the Duma : 'I wish all the deputies in the Duma were like you.'

"I would ask those Englishmen who are in favour of this alliance : 'With whom do you wish to make an alliance ? ; There are two Russias. The one, the Emperor Nicolas, the bureaucracy, and the 'Union of the Russian People'—some ten thousand of the lowest classes, led by evil and ruthless people; the other, about a hundred million Slavs, and about fifty millions belonging to the other nationalities which compose the Russian Empire. All this mass with one accord hates the Tsar and all those who are with him and those who are for him."

div.head: Housing Government Employee.
div.p: The Railway Administration is considering the construction of houses for their employees.

div.head: Al Azhar University.
div.p: A summer holiday from August 1 to No- vember 16 is to be given to the students of Al Azhar University.

div.head: Copies of Deeds.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has decided to reduce the tariff for the expenses of copying deeds from P.T. 40 to P.T. 20.

div.head: The Brindiel Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and O.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at half past four this afternoon.

div.head: Continental Hotel Concerts.
div.p: The Wednesday evening military concerts held on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, will not take place until fur- ther notice.

div.head: A Sign of the Times.
div.p: Such is the dearth of money at the present time that we learn on good authority a mortgage on excellent property in Cairo was concluded recently at 24 per cent.

div.head: Holy Land School.
div.p: The Franciscan Fathers wish to inform the public that the distribution of prizes at the Marina School will take place on the 3rd October. The school will reopen after the summer holidays on Monday, September 16th.

div.head: Cairo's Water Supply.
div.p: The Government, in combination with the Cairo Water Company, are arranging for the engagement of an international commission, consisting of English, French and German members, to analyse the water of the artesian wells and report thereon.

div.head: Rodah Water Supply.
div.p: The Island of Rodah is now included in the concession to the Cairo Water Company, which as reduced its tariff from 8 to 6 milliemes per cubic metre. The installation of the new service will be commenced im- mediately.

div.head: Sudden Deaths.
div.p: A young girl, aged 7 years, suddenly fell down dead from heart failure while crossing Sharia Abbas yesterday. Her body was con- veyed to hospital for purposes of post mortem examination. In a similar way a native agent of secret police dropped down dead in Sharia Chamacherghi, Shoubra, while holding conversation with his captain, Ali Abou Gabal.

div.head: Ambassador's Embarrassed.
div.p: The Hague Conference does not seem to bring about any very important results. The question of languages is the principal obstacle to an easy understanding between the numer- ous ambassadors. It is more and more necessary, in careers, to know thoroughly several foreign languages. The Berlitz School, 1 Sharia Kamel,-12 rue Rosette Alexandria, and at the Carlton, Hotel, Ramleh. [Advt.]

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Youssef Bey Cussa, son of the late Franco Pasha, who has been appointed Governor of the Lebanon in succession to the late Muzaffer Pasha, has occupied many important posts in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs at Stamboul. Youssef Bey, who is about 50 years, has been popular throughout his official career, and has the great advantages of knowing thoroughly several languages.
Mustapha Pasha Ibadi will return from leave on September 19.
Mohamed Shoukri Pasha, Mudir of Menou- fieh, is leaving for Europe to-day and will return on the 9th October.
Dr. Abbate Pasha left for Syria yesterday with his daughter Mrs. Vernon Jarvis, and will return to Cairo early in August.
Miralai T. Schalch Bey, Commandant of the Suez Canal Police, will go on leave for 2 1/2 months, dating from the 17th instant.
It is said that Moussa Pasha Ghaleb, ex- director of the El Wadi teftish, will succeed Rachid Pasha Mohamed as member of the Legislative Council.

The following officers of the Egyptian Army are on leave and will return on the under- mentioned dates:-Miralai Owen Bey, C.M.G., Director of Intelligence and Sudan Agent, October 10, Kaimakam Drury Bey, Controller, Harbours and Lights, November 5 ; Kaima- kam Brakenridge Bey, Medical Corps, Sep- tember 15 ; Bimbashi Hills, Department of Supplies, September 17 ; Bimbashi Hamilton, attached Bahr El Ghazal District, September 17 ; Bimbashi Coke, 10th Sudanese, Septem- ber 17.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN ESTATES LIMITED.
SATISFACTORY REPORT.
div.p: London, Wednesday.

The Egyptian Estates Limited has just issued its annual report for the year ending on the 31st March last. The report on the twelve months' working show that the profits have amounted to £178,000. £63,700 have been placed to the reserve fund and £15,000 to the special reserve fund, thus leaving £100,000 as net profits. The board of directors do not propose paying any further dividend for the present, an interim dividend of five per cent having been paid a few months ago.
The annual general meeting of the share- holders of the Company will be held on the 26th inst.
Arrangements are now being made for a new issue of debentures.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN MOTOR TRACTION COMPANY.
THE QUESTION OF LIQUIDATION.
div.p: It is curious that while motor busses seem to do so well in Cairo and are such a familiar feature in the streets of the Capital, yet at Alexandria the Egyptian Motor Traction Com- pany has had to withdraw its busses and the company will hold a meeting on Tuesday next, the 16th inst., to decide as to whether it should go into liquidation.

The Company was established in 1906 under Egyptian law to provido a motor omnibus service for Alexandria and the district. The capital consisted of 15,000 shares of £4 each and there were 1,200 founders shares of no denomination. The directors were E. Delta, E. Giglio, N. Paraskevas, Alfred Suares and Clement Suares. The managing director was A. Kempner.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING COMPANY. LIMITED.
div.p: We continue to receive correspondence on the subject of the position of the above un- fortunate undertaking. We, however, refrain from publishing further criticisms in the hope that the members of the board of direction will be able to arrive at a decision, which will not jeopardise the interests of their shareholders.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LIMITED.
div.p: The well-known firm of Grant, Bondi and Chinn, branch of the Egyptian Constructions Limited, has secured the contract for the new system of drainage at the new reformatory at Ghizeh. This class of work is quite new for this country and must be most interesting. Engineers and specialists interested will be given free access to see the work in progress.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
div.p: The London correspondent of a Cairo Con- temporary states that a company has been formed in Hull, with a capital of £1,000 in £1 shares, for the purpose of acquiring the Egypt ian branch of the confectionery business White and Son, Limited, of Hull, to undertake in Egypt, the Sudan, and elsewhere the representation and agency for manufacturers, exporters and merchants, etc. The directors (not less than two nor more than seven) are : W. L. White, T. L. White, J. D. White, and W. L. White, jur. The registered offices of the Company, which is styled White and Son (Egypt), Limit- ed, are in Cumberland Street, Hull.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH.
div.p: Sheikh Aly Youssef; the editor and pro- prietor of "Al Moayad", who is now at Constan- tinople, states that the health of the Sultan is excellent and that he was simply suffering from cold and pains in the kidneys last winter. He heard the Khedive declare in Constanti- nople that he never saw the Sultan in a better state of health then he now is.

div.head: CAIRO STATION BUFFET.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—Referring to the article headed "Cairo Station" which appeared in your issue of the 2nd instant, I beg to inform you that a three years' lease of the Cairo Station buffet was granted to the present tenant on January 1st 1906, and has not yet been renewed. Yours faithfully,
div.note: [In publishing the above dementi to the rumour that the lease of the Cairo Station buffet had been renewed for three years, we would remark that we trust that the Adminis- tration will see their way to supplying as soon as possible a restaurant and cafe for the use of first class passengers, ae we consider the present buffet altogether inadequate. Ed. E.G.]

div.head: SAVOY PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: The Administration of the Savoy Palace Hotel at Alexandria requests us to announce that it has decided to close the hotel from June 15 to October 1. [ADVT.]

div.head:
PLAGUE IN ALEXANDRIA.
THREE HOTEL CASES.
div.p: A considerable sensation was caused in, Alexandria yesterday afternoon by the news that three cases of plague, one of which has proved fatal, had occurred in the Hotel de la Poste, situated in the Post Office Street.

Referring to the plague bulletin issued by the Quarantine Board for the period from midday yesterday to midday to-day, we find that there have been 5 fresh cases, and 1 death, 1 old case in this town being still under treat- ment, thus making 7 in all, and it is a notable fact that all of these cases are Europeans.
Since the first of January there have been in all 32 cases of plague, of which 16 have proved fatal, 11 have been cured, and five remain under treatment.

Of the recent cases which we report, one was an Austrian, who was admitted to hospital on the 8th inst. and succumbed to the malady, and one a Belgian engineer, who was taken to hospital yesterday and is in a precarious con- dition. Both these cases occurred in the Hotel de la Poste, where there had already been one case reported on the 7th inst. The unfortunate man who has met his death from this terrible disease was proprietor of the hotel, Pierre Agulhon, by name. The deceased was 64 years of age. He died at one o'clock yesterday morning, and the funeral took place at 6 p.m. the same day.
Of the other cases recorded, one is that of a woman living near Rue Anastassi, and two are Russian Jews, one of whom had been working in a shop behind the Hotel de la Poste.

Needless to say, yesterday about midday the Quarantine authorities took the usual steps to isolate the infected hotel, and, being in so central a position, crowds were soon attracted to stand round and gape. Those living in the hotel were placed in a most awk- ward predicament. None were allowed out, and those who were out were refused entry, so that their business was sadly interfered with.

One most awkward case which has come to our knowledge is that of Mr. Bert Flatt, the popular American musical comedian, now billed on the programme of the Tour Eiffel. Returning to his hotel in the afternoon Mr. Flatt was refused admission, but on protest was conducted to his room by a police officer. The authorities, however, refused to allow him to take his clothes away before they had been disinfected. Mr. Flatt then left the hotel, locking the door and taking his key with him, and communicated with his consul. Noth- ing, however, could be done, and, returning later to make another attempt to get his dress suit so that he might not fail his audience, once inside he was imprisoned there and not allowed out until abont eleven o'clock this morning. Before leaving, however, he was allowed to pack his suits and hand over his dirty linen, etc., for disinfection.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL ADVISER.
div.p: A Cairo newspaper made the following an- nouncement yesterday:—

"The rumour that Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, would shortly retire is correct. Sir Vincent Corbett will not return to Egypt after he goes on leave but it is thought that he will be given a post in the diplomatic ser- vice. It seems likely that Chitty Bey will succeed Sir Vincent Corbett as financial ad- viser".

This information is not quite correct for although Sir Vincent Corbett has expressed a wish to leave the service of the Egyptian Government and go back to the Diplomatic Ser- vice, no decision as to whether he will return to Egypt or not has yet been taken.
The "Egyptian Standard," in quoting our contemporary who made the above statement, makes the following amusing remarks :—

"We may add to the above remarks that Sir Eldon Gorst has already set to work on height- ening the efficiency of the various departments and requesting the veterans of the Administra- tion to retire and cede to younger men who have not been touched by the spirit of Cro- merism".

Sir Vincent Corbett only came to Egypt in 1903 when he was appointed British Commissioner on the Caisse de la Dette so he cannot be considered a veteran, but this attribute is only on a par with the amazing local ignorance for which Kamel's English organ is notorious.

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: The Official Journal has recently issued a French translation of the motions made at the last meeting of the General Assembly. The political aspects of the various proposi- tions received a great deal of attention at the time in our columns, but there are some quaint proposals of a purely social character, which have not been noticed. For instance, to quote only one example, Mohamed Bey Souk- kar, brought forward a motion, which is given as follows in the "Journal Officiel":-

Dans l'interet des bonnes moeurs et de la pudeur, il conviendrait d'empecher les femmes de se montrer sur la voie publique dans une attitude provocante pouvant les confondre avec les femmes publiques, car si la loi defend a ces dernieres de se montrer dans de pareilles attitudes, elle doit, a plus forte raison, etre plus soucieuse de sauvegarder les bonnes moeurs des premieres. La loi n'etant pas appli- quee, je propose de demander au Gouverne- ment s'il l'approuve, de faire executer la loi.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS, LIMITED.
REPORT FOR THE YEAR.
div.p: The following is the Report of the Di- rectors of The Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, for the year ended 31st March, 1907, which will be presented to the pro- prietors at the tenth ordinary general meeting to be hold on Tuesday, the 23rd inst. at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, E.G., at 3 p.m. o'clock:—
The directors submit herewith the accounts of the company for the year ended 31st March, 1907.

LINES OPENED TO TRAFFIC.—At the 31st March. 1906, 908 kilometres (say 564 miles) of line were open for traffic. During the year under review further sections equal to 17 kilo- metres have been opened, making a total of 925 kilometres (say 574-70 miles), open and working at 31st March, 1907, as under :—

REVENUE ACCOUNT.—The average mileage open during the year was 571 as compared with 566 miles open during the year ended 31st March, 1906. The following figures give the average mileage and receipts for the two periods:-
Year ended. March 31st, 1906 : — Gross receipts £224,142. Average mileage open 556. Average receipts per mile per year £403 2 7. Average receipts per mile per week. £7 15 0.
Year ended. March 31st, 1907 : — Gross receipts £255,782. Average mileage open 571. Average receipts per mile per year £447 19 1. Average receipts per mile per week £8 12 3.
The Directors are of opinion that the gross receipts for the current year are satisfactory.

Coaching.—The coaching traffic has improved in a most marked manner, the number of passengers carried during the year having been 7,050,882, as compared with 6,008,507 for the year ended 31st March, 1906, an increase of 1,042,375. The gross receipts from this source amounted to £155,504 Os 11d., an increase of £24,508 15s 8d., equal to about 18 7O per cent over the year 1906, the average per mile per week having improved from £5 4s. 8d. to £4 10s. 7d. The statement below shews the number of passengers carried and the receipts from each class for the past three years.

GOODS.—The receipts from Goods Traffic have also shown satisfactory improvement. During the year 1,120,913 tons were lifted as compared with 1,139,440 tons in 1906, the gross receipts being £90,040, an increase of £8,153, more than 9 1/2 per cent, over the pre- vious year. The table below gives the tonnage lifted and the receipts from the principal com- modities carried during the past two years :-

row.cell: Other Articles of Merchandise and Sundries
Other Articles of Merchandise and Sundries

div.p: WORKING EXPENSES.—Notwithstanding in- creased cost of coal, payment of better salaries and more expensive labour, the proportion of Working Expenses to Receipts was 57.35 per cent, as compared to 58.59 per cent last year.

DIVIDEND.—The net earnings for the year from all sources, as shewn by the Net Revenue Account, amounted to £109,095 4s. 1d., which with interest, &o, earned amounting to £6,649 6s. 3d., and £31,044 4s. 0d. brought forward from 1906, gives the grand total of £146,788 14s. 14s. 4d. to be dealt with.

After providing for Interest on the Deben- ture and Share Capital Redemption Sinking Funds, Reserves, &c., a balance of £63,968 14a. 1Od remains, of which a Dividend of 2 per cent, paid in December, 1906, absorbed £20,815 12s. 0d., leaving £43,153 2s. 1Od. available for distribution. The Board now re- commend the payment of a further Dividend of 3 1/2 per cent on the Preference Share Capi- tal, making a total of 5 1/2 per cent for the year, which will absorb £36,427 6s. 0d., leaving a balance of £6,725 16s. 10d. to be car- ried forward.

METROPOLITAN AND CAIRO-HELOUAN RAIL- ROAD CONCESSION.—In the Directors' Report for the year ended 30th September, 1905, the Proprietors were informed that the Egyptian Government had consented to a modification of the Terms of the Concession covering the Cairo-Helouan Section of Line, by the ex- tension of the date upon which. Government first has the option of purchasing the Line. Negotiations with Government have since been proceeding as to the terms of this extension, and the Directors are able to report that satisfactory arrangements have now been made whereby the date of this option is extended to the 1st Novem- ber, 1927, for an expenditure by the company of L.E. 60,000 in very necessary improvements on the Helouan branch. Further minor modifi- cations of the terms of the original concession dealing principally with questions of Govern- ment inspection of the lines, rolling stock, and the construction by Government of branch lines, crossings, &c., have been mutually agreed upon. The agreement is now ready for execution, and the proprietors will be asked to approve and pass the resolution set out on the back of this notice authorising the directors to enter into the same with the Egyptian Gov- ernment.

CAIRO LIME STONE QUARRIES. — Construc- tion work on this section of line is practically completed, 12 kilometres were ready to be opened at the 31st March, and only a little work remains to be done to enable the opening of the whole section of 16 kilometres.

INVESTMENTS. — In the last report, the pro- prietors were informed that part of the Shares in the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, the funds for the pur- chase of which had been provided from share premium account, had been disposed of. During the past year the balance of these shares were sold. These sales were necessitated by the fact that the land company desired to alter its memorandum of association and that the alterations proposed would not admit of the railway company, under its memorandum of association, retaining its interest.
The conditions imposed by the courts before authorising these alterations not proving ac- ceptable to the land company, the matter fell through.

Under these circumstance, it was deemed desirable that the railway company's interest and control should be re-acquired, and the shares were accordingly re-purchased at the sale price under an arrangement with the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co., Ltd.

DIRECTORS.—Sir Auckland Colvin, K.C.S.I., K.C.M.G., C.I.E.; Mr. Montagu Sharpe, and Maurice Cattaui Bey, directors of the company, retire by rotation, and being eligible offer themselves for re-election.
AUDITORS—The proprietors will be asked to elect auditors for the coming year, and Messrs. Meredith and Co., being eligible, offer them- selves for re-election.

div.head: LORD CROMERS GRANT.
div.p: On the 2nd inst. Mr. Kettle asked the Prime Minister whether the proposed vote of £50,000 to Lord Cromer, for his services in Egypt, would be submitted to the House by way of resolution, and, if so, was he able to announce the terms of the resolution, and the date on which it would be introduced.

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman : Any step which may be taken in such a matter must originate with a message from the Crown, and until such a message is received, it would be premature and improper to make any statement.

Mr. W. Redmond : I beg to give notice that should the unprecedented course be token of giving Lord Cromer a money reward for ser- vices for which he is already well paid, I shall oppose the resolution.

div.head: BORTON BEY'S APPOINTMENT.
div.p: The appointment of Borton Bey as Postmaster General led Mr. Swift McNeill, the Irish Nationalist M. P. to ask the following question last week in the House of Commons:—

Whether Borton Bey, who, on the retirement of Saba Pasha, a native, has been appointed Postmaster General of Egypt, has only two years' experience of postal administration ; whether the British Consul General has in this case departed from the policy laid down by Lord Cromer in his Report for 1906, of ap- pointing competent natives to the higher administrative posts, provided that experiments of that kind already made should be successful; and whether it is in consequence of the failure of such experiments that an Englishman has in this instance been substituted for a native.
In reply Sir Edward Grey said : I have no information on the point raised by the hon. member, but I will enquire.

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: Mr. Swift Mac Neill asked the Secretory of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, seeing that Lord Cromer in his despatch of 8th March (Egypt, No. 3, 1907), complained that many of the 85 proposals laid before the Egyptian General Assembly were discussed in a very perfunctory manner, and that it was impossible in the space of three days to discuss them adequately, he will state upon whose initiative, and upon what grounds, the session of the Assembly was thus curtailed ; and whether he will advise the Egyptian Government that in future the General Assembly should meet annually instead of, as at present, once in two years, and should be allowed sufficient time to deliberate on the proposals laid before it.

Sir Edward Grey—With regard to the point of the hon. member's question I have no infor- mation, but will enquire. I am not at present aware of any reason for altering the regula- tions respecting the meeting of the Assembly about which, so far as I known, no complaint has been made.
Mr. Mac Neil—Will the right hon. gentle- man enquire by telegraph?
Sir Edward Grey.—I do not think this is a case for enquiring by telegram.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie hier après-midi, sous la présidence de Yehia pacha, en l'absence de Schiess pacha qui s'était fait excuser.
En ouvrant la séance, le président s'est fait l'interprète des sentiments dé l'assemblee, en exprimant ses vifs regrets pour la perte dou- lourense que vient d'éprouver Schiess pacha.

— Communication a été donnée d'une note de l'Ingénieur en chef proposant de confier a une entreprise les travaux de réparations de certaines rues, asphaltées depuis plusieurs années. Ces réparations sont faites actuellement par la Municipalité, les entrepreneurs n'ayant charge de les réparer que pendant une période de dix ans après leur asphaltage. L'ingénieur en chef propose dé charger une entreprise, de toutes les réparations des rues asphaltées moyennant un prix à déterminer. La Déléga- tion a décidé de provoquer des offres à ce su- jet pour se rendre compte du prix auquel lui reviendraient ces réparations confiées à l'entre- prise privée.

— Conformément a l'avis du Comité des travaux publics, la Délégation a décidé l'ou- verture d'un crédit de 3,000 livres pour chan- ger les regards des égouts et pour l'essai du système de ventilation des égouts proposé par l'ingénieur en chef, dans les rues oh une cana- lisation définitive est établie.
— Sur la proposition de l'ingenieur en chef, la Délégation a décidé de procéder au dallagu des nouveaux quais au Port-Est et des rues aboutissant.

La dépense serait de 44,000 livres, la sur face à daller étant de dix mille mètres carrés. M. l'Administrateur est chargé de faire, pour la rentrée, des propositions en vue de trouver les moyens pour faire face aux dépenses.
-La Delegation a adjugé a M'.Carlo Pini, pour la somme de 3,475 livres, les travaux de construction d'une annexe au Palais Municipal.
-Elle a pris note de l'état des recettes et des dépenses du 1er janvier au 30 juin 1907.
-Elle a renvoyé au Comité des travaux publics un devis présenté pour la construction d'un batiment affecté a la manipulation des restés d'animaux, a l'abattoir du Mex.

-La Delegation s'est occupée en dernier lieu des mesures à prendre pour la surveillance des constructions, conformément au nouyeau réglement qui entrera en vigueur trente jours après sa publication dans le "Journal Officiel."

div.head:
KING EDWARD'S TOUR.
ADDRESS AT HOLYHEAD.
TRANQUILLITY OF EUROPE.

div.p: Replying to an address at Holyhead on his way to Ireland, the King said that the pros- perity of the country was bound to be imperill- ed by any disturbance of the tranquillity of Europe. He hoped that the high position occu- pied by Great Britain among the nations would always be maintained by peaceful means. "As far as in me lies," said His Majes- ty, "her influence shall ever be devoted to the promotion of friendship and goodwill." (R.)

div.head:
SAN FRANCISCO SCANDALS.
THE MAYOR SENTENCED.

div.p: The Mayor, Schmitz, has bee sentenced to 5 years' imprisonment. (Reuter)

div.head:
HOUSE OF COMMONS.
EVICTED TENANTS BILL.

div.p: The Evicted Tenants' Bill has passed the second reading by 315 votes to 98. (Reuter)

The "Daily Mail" learns from Berlin that the Japanese naval commission has given Krupp's the order for the new Japanese "Dreadnought" 12 inch guns. It will occupy 9 months. The order was not placed with English works because they were already fully occupied. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
KOREA AND ITS EMPEROR.

div.p: In view of the despatch of delegates to the Hague the Korean Government is appointing a committee of control over the Emperor's pri- vate purse, in order to prevent illegal disbur- sements. (Reuter)
The Government has decided to provide 30,000,000 roubles a year, up to 1911, for the construction and armament of new warships. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE MACEDONIAN SITUATION
DEPUTATION TO SIR E. GREY.
GREAT BRITAIN'S INFLUENCE.

div.p: Replying to a deputation, headed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, urging that more vigorous British action should be taken in Macedonia, Sir E. Grey admitted that the situation was as unsatisfactory as ever. He had warned the Governments failing to sup- press marauding bands in their own territories that they alienate from themselves the sym- pathy of Europe. He dwelt on the danger of isolated British action, but Great Britain, he said, would use her influence to prevent the Powers becoming callous. (Reuter)

The French controller, delegated for the service of the Moroccan loan, has been con- ferring since this morning with the collectors charged with examining the customs dues for the admission of merchandise. (Havas)
The Senate has ratified the liberation of class 1903. (Havas)
A letter from the King prorogues the Diet. (Havas)
A new Transvaal flag has been adopted. It is composed of four colours with the Union Jack in the upper left hand corner. (Reuter)

div.head:
EL RAISULI UNEASY.
SIR H. MACLEAN REMOVED.

div.p: El Raisuli, feeling unsafe in the Kmass district, has removed with Sir H. Maclean to a lonely spot on the borders of the Beniaros tribe. (Reuter)

div.head: ABUSE OF "BITTERS."
div.p: The growth of the "drug habit" is the sub- ject of comment in the current issue of "The Lancet." The drinking of bitters associated with alcohol (the article proceeds) easily becomes a habit.

The choice of a "bitter" is widening, so that now men may be found calling for soda-water and quinine, and the demand is not likely to be refused by the managers of a depart- ment which is profitable. Vermuth is the favourite with a good many, and a consider- able quantity is consumed at golf clubs, the drinker of it being quite unconscious of the fact as described in our text-books that oil of wormwood "is a convulsive poison." We may not unreasonably expect gentian, calumba, chiretta, and so on shortly to be added to the materia medica of the drinking-bar. In disease bitters are a powerful aid, for they are tonics, increasing appetite and encouraging the assimilation of food; in health they may easily prove to be mischievous and be pro- ductive of evil rather than of good; they will irritate the stomach and induce indigestion.

It is with bitters as with alcohol; both are drugs, and the chronic and excessive in- dulgence in drugs does not, as a rule, help to maintain the normal vigour of the healthy body. When a man finds he cannot distinguish between use and abuse his safe course is, observes "The Lancet," to be abstemious."

div.head: HOW COULD SHE?
div.p: A Yale professor claims woman was the in- ventor of the kiss. Let us be thankful she didn't keep it to herself.-"Chicago Journal."

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET.
div.p: We are awaiting the arrival to-morrow of the British fleet in this port. It was announced yesterday that instead of arriving, as was expected, on the 16th, it would reach here on the 5th. It is unfortunate that the ships should arrive at this 'dead season', when the place is too hot for any form of entertain- ments, and when the few resident English officials are absent either on leave or at Troodos. On the present occasion the district Com- mission is on the eve of his departure for England and the other officials are on the point of sending their families to cooler regions.

No doubt, if the fleet will stay sufficiently long, several of the officer's will seize the opportunity of visiting Troodos, where accomo- dation of a sort can probably be found and a few days in the hills will be the pleasantest mode in which they could possibly spend their time.

While writing (8 a.m.) two cruisers have just anchored in the bay, viz : The "Suffollk" 9800 tons armoured 1st class cruiser and the "Lancaster" 9800 tons, armoured twin screw cruiser. In order to test their speed they have made a quick passage from Alexandria, covering the distance in 13 hours, at 20 knots an hour.

The eleven vessels expected, here and at Larnaca and Famagusta carry a total com- plement of about 7,000 officers and men. The sudden advent of so large a number of men with healthy appetites, would afford a good chance to the peasantry to sell their fruit and vegetables at first hand. If only timely notice could be furnished to the villages in the neighbourhood many a small farmer would be enabled to make a welcome little harvets, by selling his produce at consumer's instead of at merchant's prices.

It is noteworthy that to-day the Union Jack, which at other times is conspicuously absent, is seen waving from every hotel, restaurant and coffee-house of any standing, frequently in solitary grandeur. It is regarded as likely to prove a useful asset and to have a solid money value, so sentiment goes to the wall.

div.head: New Limassol Hotel.
div.p: The new Grand Hotel Amathus is a welcome addition to this place. Its proprietor, W. I. L. Rossides, has experience of hotel management, . as he owns a high class hotel in Constantinople. He has selected a building immediately over- looking the sea, and close upon the beach. The rooms facing seawards have therefore the advantage of fresh air, and are shut off from the many aggressive street noises which are a specially disagreeable feature of this town. The arrangement of the rooms, the style of furnishing, the table appointments and so forth, are superior to what we generally find in other establishments of the kind in Cyprus ; though it must be admitted that the charges are some- what higher. The following menu for dinner is we believe, a fair sample : Soup, Bonchees a la reine, Poisson mayonnaise, Gigot a la printaniere, Poulet roti, Salade, Compote, dessert, glaces, cafe : excellently served. Price 2/4 1/2 cp. (2/6d). Other charges are Break- fast 1/- Lunch 1/4 1/2 Rooms 2/- to 2/4 1/2 cp. It might be in the interests of the hotel to make an inclusive charge of say 6/- per day. The endeavour to introduce something in the nature of a really good hotel is worthy of encouragement and we trust that before long similar establishments may bestarted at Nicosia and Larnaca.

div.head: Personal.
div.p: Mr. J. Kirke, who, for some years, has been assisting in the management of the English wine factory at Perapedlis, is leaving for England by this mail. He has been for some months in an unsatisfactory state of health, and is now proceeding home on medical advice. His departure, and the reasons for it, will be regretted by a large circle of friends whom be leaves behind and by whom he is held in much esteem. The villagers of Perapedlis and the neighbourhood, will feel that in him they are losing a very good friend.

div.head: Unusual Damp Weather.
div.p: Consequent upon sea mists this town has been experiencing some days of unusually damp heat. The thermometer, however, has not risen much above 86 F.

div.head: SIR LUKE FILDES AND THE YOKEL.
div.p: "Sir Luke Fildes," says a writer in the "Pen- ny Magazine," "tells a funny story concerning the man who possed for the bridegroom in "The Village Wedding." Soon after he had begun work the artist noticed that the model became very pale. He made him take a rest, and then began work again. The model soon became whiter than ever. 'What's the matter?' asked Fildes. 'You don't seem very well.' 'I be a'right, zur,' answered the model, 'only this holding the breath do be main hard!' The poor fellow imagined that he must hold his breath all the while be was being 'took.'"

div.head: CHILD LIFE.
div.p: Overheard in front of a stationer's window in Eccles :- First Little Girl (eagerly pointing to a picture postcard of the Whit week procession); "You see Mary Anne there?" Second Little Girl: "Yess." Well, you see them boots behind her?" Yes." "Well, that's me!"-"Manchester Guardian.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
MR. WILFRID BLUNT.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

May I point out to you, sir, one item of Mr. Wilfred Blunt's "exposures" which has not apparently had sufficient attention paid it. It is that while the British were going to war with Arabi Pasha, he, Mr. Blunt, acted as traitor and spy, seeking information as to the projected movement of troops from Army officials and handing on that information to the enemy, and causing thereby the protracted resistance and additional loss of life at Tel-el- Kebir. May I ask you, sir, to give this point its full value and that even though it may be too late for him to receive the punishment the action deserved, his character may yet be made known in its true light to the worid, and from that knowledge may he receive the treat- ment due to traitors, which in former times meant an ignominious death.
I am, sir, Yours faithfully,

div.head: THE LIFE THAT EBBS AWAY.
HOW PINK PILLS BRING IT BACK IN FULL VIGOUR.
div.p: "As the result of a miscarriage I fell ill," writes Signora Collini Luigia, "and it seemed to me that my life was ebbing away little by little. I felt perfectly convinced that if no- thing came to stop my increasing weakness- every day becoming worse-I could not es- cape death. I had no longer any appetite, I ate almost nothing, yet in spite of that I digested with the greatest difficulty the little food that I took, and I suffered regularly from cramps and gripings. I also had difficulty of breathing. My weakness was such that even when sitting or lying down I had at- tacks of vertigo. At night, I got no repose ; either I lay awake or such sleep as I got was made a fatigue and a torture to me by terrible nightmares.

"In the daytime I was troubled incessantly by noises in the ears and my sight often became dim. I had on the advice of various people followed several courses of treatment, but all were without result, and I despaired of finding any cure.

"At last a priest, a friend of my husband, who had seen some remarkable cures accom- plished by Pink Pills, induced my husband to make me take them. Pink Pills had an effect truly marvellous on my health. I rapidly recovered my strength and was soon in enjoy- ment of all the good health that I could desire. My cure by its rapidity and completeness has absolutely astonished all my friends and ac quaintances.
"Once again I was able to devote my time to my children. For a long time they had been deprived of my care."

Mme Cellini Luigia lives at Marola (Spezia), Via Provinciale No. 5 Her age is thirty-nine. Mme. Cellini Luigia was in the same perilous position as those moun- tain guides who often roll down a precipice and miracoulously save their lives by hanging on to a frail branch or a projecting piece of rock. They see death coming, as it were ; they count the moments of life which remain to them. If some intervention of Providence comes not to rescue them from their terrible plight they are lost. Pink Pills were for Mme Cellini this Provi- dential interposition. Other medicines had failed to do her any good, and who knows what would have become of her had she not made use of this remarkable regenerator of blood, this powerful tonic of the nervous system?

Pink Pills are the medicine which restore the organism. For this reason they are ordered for convalescents. It is well known that in certain epidemic maladies the organism is in a state of complete enfeeblement.
Pink Pills, through their action on the blood and the nerves are a sovereign preventative, and a remedy for anemia, chlorosis, neuras- thenia, general debility, stomach disorders, and rheumatism.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN BOOM.
div.p: BY SIR R. HAMILTON LANG.
(Continued.)

The rise in cotton in 1899 from 9 1/4 tal- leris to 12 5/8 talleris unexpectedly raised the value of the Daira lands, and it is under- stood that the profits of the enterprise have exceeded six millions sterling, half of which reverts to the Egyptian Government. Pro- fiting by the ready demand and enhanced prices, the new Daira Sanieh Co. proceeded to sell their newly acquired lands, payable in annuities of from ten to fifteen years. Companies were formed to purchase them, and the speculative boom set in. Cotton continuing to rise, lands steadily increased in value, and handsome profits were made. The purchases made in 1900, when cotton was at 12 5/8 talleris, left a large margin of profit in 1902, when cotton had gone up to 16 1/4 talleris, and there was a still larger margin when in 1906 it went to 18 talleris. In 1907, cotton having reached an average of 10 1/4 talleris, the acme of the boom seemed to have been reached, and cotton lands worth £40 an acre in 1907 gradually rose to £200. As an example of what took place. I may cite the case of a purchaser who bought from the new Daira Sanieh Co. an estate for which the purchase price was £60,000, payable in annuities. Shortly after he had paid the first annuity of £6000 he was offered by, and accepted from, a syn- dicate the reimbursement of £6000 he had paid, plus a bonus of £40,000. The rise in the value of land was so steady and so considerable, that speculators made large profits from one year to another.

The interesting question for the future, which I heard discussed by many competent authorities in Egypt, is, "Are the present high prices for agricultural land justified and likely to be permanent?" It was generally admitted that with cotton at 19 1/4 talleris the present prices of land seem justified, but their permanence entirely depends upon the future value of cotton. On this latter point the pros- pects are undoubtedly favourable. The present production of cotton is not in excess of the consumption of the world, and the increase of production which can be hoped for in the near future does not exceed the steady in- crease of consumption. The United States of America, which contribute fully four fifths of the cotton supply of the world, seem to have nearly reached the maximum of their pro- ductive power in cotton, and all the laudable efforts to develop the cultivation of cotton in British colonies have, so far, yielded very feeble results. South America and India re- main the most hopeful centres for increas- ed supplies, but they will do little more, for a long time, than satisfy the constantly in- creasing consumption. However, it must not be lost sight of that the pecuniary position of "a cultivator in Egypt may be as much affect- ed by the yield of his crop as by its price. Atmospheric influences reducing our four- fifths supply from America would find imme- diate compensation in enhanced prices ; but such influences reducing the yield in Egypt, which supplies only one-seventh of the world's production, might not obtain a full compen- sation in an enhancement of price. Thus a yield of only 5 millions of cantars (in 1898 the yield was only 4 1/2 millions, while that of the preceding and the succeeding year was 6 1/2 millions), instead of 7 millions in the present year, would temporarily impoverish the culti- vators, and be as detrimental to them as a fall in the price of cotton to 15 talleris.

While, therefore, it may be admitted that there is a very fair prospect of the continu- ance of a high level in the price of cotton, and consequently a justification of the present value of agricultural land in Egypt, the pos- sibility of various adverse influences ought to make speculators in land cautious and bankers prudent in making advances upon mortgage.

As much, I fear, cannot be said in regard to the very high prices to which urban pro- perties have been pushed by speculators in Cairo and Alexandria. There the rise has re- latively far exceeded that in agricultural lands, and in as far as it has exceeded it, I am inclined to think it is fictitious. Take, for example, the well authenticated case in Cairo, to which I have already alluded, of a small villa, worth twelve years ago £3000, being sold for £32,000. The purchaser, to secure 5 per cent on his capital, will require a rental of over £1500 for a villa capable of accomodating only a small and modest family. This he cannot hope to get. He might pull down the present house and, taking in the small garden behind it, build a lofty block of flats, but even then the initial cost of the land would be an exces- sive burden. What took place in Buda-Pesth is likely to be repeated in Cairo. Some thirty years ago a building-mania developed in Buda- Pesth. Magnificent structures were erected, chiefly with borrowed money. Over-building brought about a " krach ". Property fell ra- pidly in value, and many were ruined. True, we rejoice to-day in a handsomely built town with very moderate rents, but we forget the heavy losses which the building spec- ulators incurred. At present, purchases of town lands in Egypt are mostly payable in annuities extending over as many as thirty years, and bearing interest at 5 per cent, with a mortgage upon the property. As in time some of these mortgagee may be foreclosed, the value of house property will probably decrease. The collapse may not be sudden,— indeed it is to be hoped that the process of depreciation may be gradual. The first seller, who thought he had made a huge profit, may have to sac- rifice a part of that profit, but will still remain a gainer. In fact, the colossal profit of a seller on long annuities is in great part only a paper profit, which in some cases may not be fully realised.

To resume my impression of the future prospects of the present high value of agri- cultural land and urban land, I would say that the former, considering the probability of a continuance of high prices for cotton, seems justified, but that the latter has been pushed up by speculators to an exagger- ated level which cannot, in all likelihood, be maintained.

With the large profits on cotton since 1902, one might have expected to find that the debts upon mortgage in the country would have diminished. Quite the contrary has taken place. From an interesting and able study of these debts by Dr. Alfred Eid, we learn that they rose from £6,700,000 in 1901 to £39,000,000 in 1906; and to-day they are probably not less than £42,000,000. The landed proprietors, with few exceptions, squandered their profits, and in many cases borrowed money to purchase rural or urban property. Speculators largely bought similar property, payable in long annuities, with a view to its re-sale at a profit .Thus this great accumulation of debt has come about.
Dr. Alfred Eid divides the debts of the country against mortgages, in 1906, into three categories:—

row.cell: Those for land bought pay- able in annuities
Those debts due to banks against mortgages
Those debts due to societies and private individuals

div.p: The first category, repayable in annuities extending over a number of years, presents only a moderate annual burden; and the second and third categories are in hands which have no interest to put undue pressure upon their debtors. The present large mort- gage debt is probably, in consequence of the higher value of property, as well secured as was the smaller amount in 1901; but there are evidences that its volume is as much as if not more than, the credit and resources of the country can comfortably carry. With a wise forbearance on the part of the cre- ditors of the second and third categories towards their debtors there is, however, no reason to anticipate a crisis from that large indebtedness. With agriculturally prosperous years it will be gradually reduced.

Money stringency is being felt in Egypt, but it is chiefly in connection with the Bourse. There is no sale for the shares of a large num- ber of the companies which have been floated in recent years, and bankers naturally refuse to continue advances upon stocks which are unsaleable. The shares of even sound concerns had been forced up too high by speculative, not investment, buyers, who, unable to keep up their margins, suffer from the effects of forced sales. The result is individual losses, but the market will right itself on a sounder basis. Egypt possesses few capitalists. She is financed from abroad, and the unpleasant truth is beginning to be realised that there is a limit to the European capital available for investment in Egypt. That limit has been reached, and those who were speculating beyond their means find them- selves necessarily in a tight corner. Capitalists have been discouraged in England by the un- satisfactory results of a variety of Egyptian mining companies chiefly brought out in London. An investment list published in Alex- andria in July of last year enumerates seventeen of such companies, representing a subscribed capital of one and a half million sterling. All are quoted in that list at discounts varying from 25 to 90 per cent; and their total value at the prices quoted in the list was only £468,000, implying a loss of fully two-thirds of the capital subscribed. On the other hand, it is fair to admit that many Egyptian issues, other than mining, have proved very profitable; and this will be remembered, if capital in England for investment were to become more plentiful and money easier. Meantime in Egypt weak com- panies and weak holders of their shares must suffer. It is only a series of years of profitable trade which can bring bock monetary ease to Egypt. The air-bubles of speculators will collapse, but the Nile mud will continue to enrich Egypt with gold.

A class in Egypt which deserves all our sympathy is that of British functionaries Lord Cromer very rightly set his face aga- inst the speculative mania as soon as it set in, and, with a very few exceptions, it is to the credit of our countrymen holding positions under the Egyptian Government that they followed their chief in keeping aloof from the contaminating influence. They did not, therefore, gain as others around them did; but they suffer from the exor- bitant renta and greater cost of living which now prevail. Something has heen done to increase their salaries, but not nearly enough. Rents have doubled, if not trebled, which is a serious hardship to the many whose emoluments do not exceed £500 or £600 a-year. As one of them put it to me "We shall have to go to live in villages outside the town, and come out and in every day to our work." This would mean, especially for ladies, very considerable discomfort. The fact is, only those in highly paid posts can with any degree of comfort at present make two ends meet. The ultimate con- sequence, if this state of things continues, is that positions in Egypt will be less sought after, and blanks which occur will with greater difficulty be filled up. Egypt requires a good class of British functionaries and it will be regrettable for its interests that there should be any difficulty in finding them. However disagreeable an increase in budgetary expenditure may be, it would be a false economy not to enable British functionaries to live in comfort.

Much has lately been said about the unrest in Egypt. This subject naturally engaged my attention; for discontent, if justified, is a weed of rapid growth, which may seriously choke the fruits of industry and good administration. When, two years ago, the relations between Turkey and England were strained in a dispute connected with the Sinai frontier, the unrest in Egypt imported an unwelcome complica- tion into the situation,—for some there were who doubted whether, in the event of the Sultan proclaiming a "Jehad," or Holy War, the loyalty of the Egyptian soldiers could be relied upon.

One of these doubters said to me, "Although conscious that their cause was hopeless these Mohammedan soldiers would have embraced the cause of their Padishah." Fortunately the Sultan was too wise a man to allow himself to be led into suoh a struggle ; and by settling his difference with England the hopes of the discontented in Egypt were disappointed, and so long as the prudent Abdul Hamid is Sultan they are sure to continue to be dis- appointed. His political sagacity, which is great, may be relied upon as proof against a policy of hopeless adventure.

What, then, is the party of discontent in Egypt? It is personified Mustapha Kamel Pasha, who has been the avowed enemy of the British Administration in Egypt during the past twenty years. When France and England were at variance in regard to Egypt, Mustapha Kamel placed his hopes in France—hopes which were crushed when France came to an amicable agreement with England on Egyptian questions. When, more recently, Turkey and England were at variance on an Egyptian question, Mnstapha Kamel endeavoured, as we have already said, to make capital out of the imbroglio ; but his efforts were signally unsuccessful. At present, therefore, the dis- contented party in Egypt has no outside backing which can render it a serious menace to our position in Egypt.
(To be continued.)

div.head: ROYAL BOTANIC SOCIETY'S HORTICULTURAL SHOW.
div.p: There is an excellent show of entirely new appliances for spraying fruit trees, hops etc., especially the latter which are so much affected at this time by the aphis blight.

The "Novelty" pump introduced by Merry- weathers comprises a 50 gallon wooden tank, mounted on a four wheeled carriage, and fitted with a petrol motor, carrying enough petrol for 10 to 12 hours working, and arranged for spraying four trees at one time, thus affecting a great saving over the old hand spraying arrangement.

The Merryweather steam hop washing plant also has several improvements and has been largely adopted and for watering lawns, polo, golf, tennis and cricket grounds, the same firms' new garden Valiant steam pump gives first rate results. This is capable of pumping 1000 gallons per hour, although only 2 H.P., and can he wheeled or carried about by two men.

Another Merryweather invention is the new "Country House" pump, which is petrol driven, and will take its supply of water from a well and raise it to the top of the house for domestic water supply, or throw a good jet for fire extinguishing purposes.
The judges after inspection awarded this firm a gold medal for power spraying ap- paratus.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN SAINT.
div.p: It is well known that in the early centuries of the Christian era, Egypt was especially cele- brated for its religious ascetics, many of whom were canonised and addressed in the prayers of the faithful, as saints and martyrs.

It is not however so generally known to what a late period such persons flourished and were venerated, and recently Mr. W. E. Crum has edited certain documents preserved in various Arabic texts, all probably written in Cairo, and also portions of a Coptic version of the same literary material, which give the reputed life of one of the last of the ascetics named Barsauma, "the naked," who died, aged 60, in the year 1317 A.D. This biography is of interest to modern Egyptians because in the Church of Saint Mercurius in old Cairo, which was in Barsauma's time a site called Deir-Abu a-Saftin, between Fostat and the then Cairo city, is a rough picture of an old man in a state of nudity, which represents the worthy Barsauma.

According to the account of him now pub- lished, his father was a certain Al Wajth, secretary to Shajr-ad-Durr, the first Mameluke ruler of Egypt. The recital in the manuscripts informs us that Barsauma was well educated, and appears to have lived uninterestingly until his father's disease, when his uncle dispossessed him of his inheritance.

When urged to reprisals he refused, and took up the life of an ascetic upon the rubbish mounds of Old Cairo, clothed only with a nar- row loin cloth. The usual miraculous series of events now happens. Among others an adven- ture with a mighty serpent who resided in the vault beneath the church of Mercurius aforesaid.

Further wonders, wrought by the saint occurred at the same site, but their historical value is of the slightest. The interest of Mr. Crum's work which is being published in the "Proceedings of the Society of Biblical Archae- ology" lies in the material it affords for the history of the Coptic church, and for the theological vagaries of its volaries in the 14th century in Egypt.

div.head: A Bicyclist Recommends Pe-ru-na.
div.p: He says "I have been a bicyclist for over five years. Last spring I caught cold causing catarrh. I took Peruna, and am well. I often recommend Peruna to my friends."
Many Athletes Praise Pe-ru-na. Builds Up Worn-Out Systems.
Mr. John Perrauit, 385 Davidson street, Boulevard St. Paul. near Montreal , Canada, writes:

"I have been a bicyclist for over five years. Last spring I caught cold and did not take anything for it, for I thought it was not bad enough, but it came to catarrh. I was so discouraged that I didn't know what to do. I could not sleep; I always felt tired and troubled."

"Finally I began to take Peruna. After I had taken one bottle I felt better. I took another one, and now I am well. I would like to always feel as I do to-day. I often recommend Peruna to my friends."
For special directions everyone would read "The Ills of Life," a copy, of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists.
The following wholesale druggist will supply the retail drug trade in Alexandria, Egypt. E. DEL MAR.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi).

Les cours de Londres étant venus un peu plus faibles, les valeurs dirigeantes s'en sont immédiatement ressenties et leur dépression a entraîné celle de toute la cote. La plupart des valeurs traitées ou seulement abordées sont, en effet, en baisse. Les transactions ont d'ail- leurs été clairsemées comme tous ces jours passés et se sont limitées, sinon strictement au moins comme importance, à l'Agricole, National Bank, Estâtes et United.

En Cassa di Sconto c'est toujours l'incerti- tude qui prévaut. L'absence complète d'échan- ges ne permet pas d'établir un prix, même approximatif. Le cours inscrit en clôture est de 35, soit en baisse ultérieure de 2 francs sur celui d'hier.
L'Agricole, qui est le titre de tous le plus manipulé ces temps-ci, perd 3/16 à 7 3 4, et la National Bank 1/4 a 19 11/16; la Delta Light gagne, au contraire, 1/16 à 9 1/4.

En hausse également les Privilégiées Tram- ways d'Alexandrie de 155 à 157, l'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier de 264 à 265, les Lots Turcs de 164 à 166, la Banque d'Athènes de 116 1/2 4 116 3/4 et le Banco de Roma de 105 à 105 1/2.

L'Anglo American Nile tombe de 3 7,8 à 3, la Ramleh Railway de 4 13/16 à 4 3/4, l'Obli- gation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 313 a 311 1/2, la Delta Land de 1 5/8 à 1 9/16 ven- deurs, la Land Bank de 7 1/8 acheteurs à 7 1/8 vendeurs, les Estâtes de 11/16 à 5/8, la Building Lands de 2 1/4 à 2, l'Union Foncière de 4 13/16 a 4 3/4, la Banque d'Orient de 117 à 116 1/2, la Port Said Salt de 15 à 14/9, la Levant de 9/16 à 1/2, la fondateur United de 2 1/4 a 2.
Cette nouvelle dépression, presque générale pour les valeurs d'échange courant,est dûe aux offres de jour en jour plus nombreuses qui ne trouvent pas aisément de contre partie.

D'après le rapport que viennent de publier les Estâtes, les bénéfices de l'exercice s'élèvent à 178,000 livres. 63700 livres ont été placées a la réserve ordinaire, et 15,000 a la réserve spéciale. Il reste done 100,000 livres de dis- ponibles. Le Conseil d'Administration ne pro- pose cependant la distribution d'aucun divi- dende supplémentaire, du moins pour le mo- ment. L'Assemblée générale des actionnaires aura lieu le 26 courant. Des pourparlers sont en cours pour l'émission d'obligations.

L'Egyptian Motor Traction Company ayant suspendu son service d'automobiles, une assem- blée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires a été convoquée pour le 16 courant à l'effet de se prononcer sur la liquidation de la Société ou un arrangement à intervenir avec une autre société d'automobiles.

La société des Tramways d'Alexandrie a également suspendu son service d'automobiles entre la Place Mohamed Aly et Ras el-Tin, mais cette suspension est uniquement provi- soire ; la société ayant dû faire passer ses voitures sur les quais, il en est résulté une usure prématurée des caoutehouc et une nou- velle commande faite en Europe est attendue un moment à l'autre.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Mardi 9 juillet.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a haussé hier de 1/8 a 3 1/2 pour cent.

Au Stock exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié a 84 1/2. L'Unifiée a rétrogradé de 1/4 à 100 3/4. La National Bank est de- meurée inchangée à 20, de même que l'Agri- cole a 8 et la Daira Sanieh à 13 1/2. Sauf erreur de transmission télégraphique, la Delta Light est renseignée en avance de 1/8 à 9 3/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a réac- tionné de 1 franc à 685. La Banque d'Athènes est restée stationnaire à 116.

Impressionnée par l'atonie des grandes places d'Occident, l'allure de notre marché, an début de la séance de ce matin, a été calme, terne, voire quelque peu maussade. On s'attendait à un tassement sensible, même sur les valeurs dirigeantes, telles que la National Bank et l'Agricole par exemple, sur lesquelles il n'y a pourtant presque plus de flottant.

Cette langueur et ces mauvaises dispositions n'ont pas tardé, heureusement, à faire place a une certaine animation et, qui plus est, a une résistance efficace aux efforts faits par les bais- siers pour casser les cours. Il devient dé plus en plus évident que la position de place est déjà, en partie, assez assainie pour ne plus re- douter, comme en ces derniers temps, l'action délétère exercée par les fermente alarmistes. Sans aucun doute, le marché n'est pas encore complètement remis des secousses violentes qu'il vient de subir ; mais il sent que la période aigué du mal est passée et que la dépression n'a plus de marge appréciable. Aussi la con- fiance tend-elle à renaître. Elle pourrait aisé- ment favoriser un mouvement éventuel de re- prise, sans emballement certes, étant donnée la morte saison, mais dans une proportion gra- duelle qui devrait être attentivement surveillée par ceux qui tiennent à se composer à temps un portefeuille appelé à devenir lucratif même avant la reprise des affaires en automne.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na- tional a avancé à 19 7/8 et l'Agricole à 7 7/8- 15/16. La Société Générale Egyptienne a faibli à 230 et sa part à 32. La Banque d'Orient est remontée à 114-115.

Le Crédit Foncier a été délaissé a 680 ; l'obligation à lots nouvelle s'est raffermie à 262. La Daira est revenue a 13 5/8. L'Enter- prise and Development s'est alourdie à 8 1/2. La part de fondateur Agricole du Nil a été ramenée à 5. La part Héliopolis a été traitée à 9 1/4.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich sont restés à 15 3/4. Les Egyptian ont progressé à 4 7/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Constructions se sont raffermies à 0 7/16. Les Ghezireh Man- sions ont été traitées à 0 3/16 pour clôturer à 0 1/4 et les New Egyptian à 14 sh.
D'après un journal d'Alexandrie, voici la liste exacte des Banques et des personnalités financières qui ont consenti l'emprunt néces- saire à la réouverture de la Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio.

National Bank of Egypt ; Union Bank de Vienne et son groupe ; Comptoir National d'Escompte ; Swiss Bankverein ; Banque Impé- riale Ottomane ; Deutsche Orient Bank ; Sir Ernest Cassel ; M. Karl Meyer ; le chevalier G. de Metaxa.

Le comité de liquidation constitué d'accord avec la National Bank, est composé de MM. Walter Horschitz et Vittorio Luzzato, désignés par la dite Banque, et de MM. Enrico Nahman et G. Vannucci, désignés par la Cassa di Sconto.
Nous détachons d'une correspondance de Londres, en date du 3 Juillet, le passage suivant ;
"Les avis sont assez partagés dans la presse financière au sujet des perspectives du marché monétaire, mais l'opinion générale reste favorable.

'The Economist" estime que, dans les cir- constances actuelles, une détente considérable devrait se produire, tout au moins pour une durée de quelque temps et, du reste, les taux de l'escompte hors Banque ont reculé déjà d'une manière appréciable.

"D'autre part, le "Statist" fait remarquer que l'argent commence à renchérir à New-York et que les taux monétaires pourraient bien remonter. Dans ces conditions il est à sou- haiter que ceux qui sont engagés sur le marché monétaire de Londres n'abaissent pas les taux rapidement et que la Banque d'Angle- terre renforce son encaisse en Juillet et Août afin de se trouver en état de faire face aux besoins de l'antomne.

"Enfin le "Daily Chronicle" dit que tout semble indiquer que l'encaisse métallique de la Banque d'Angleterre sera considérablement fortifiée d'ici deux à trois semaines, bien que cela dépende, dans une grande mesure, de la tenue du change français. La perspective est généralement considérée comme satisfaisante et les taux d'escompte pourraient bien fléchir encore. Les vendeurs de traites se tiennent dans une grande réserve dans l'espoir que les courtiers ne pourront pas maintenir les toux à leur niveau actuel."
Les actionnaires des Grands Garages d'E- gypte sont convoqués en assemblée générale ordinaire pour le mardi 23 Juillet courant, à 5 heures de l'après-midi, au siège social au Caire.
A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil d'administration ; approbation des comptes de l'exercice 1906-1907 ; fixation du dividende; nomination de deux administrateurs, etc.

div.head: Societe Anonyme du Behera
AVIS
div.p: L'Assemblee Generale ordinaire des Action- naires tenue le 19 Mars 1907 ayant decide la distribution aux Actionnaires des 50,000 Actions Privilegiees 5% de 5 nominales cha- cune restees a la souche, solde des 100,000 creees en vertu de la deliberation de l'Assem- blee Generale Extradordinaire des Actionnaires du 14 Mars 1905, Messieurs les Actionnaires sont prevenus que cette operation commencero a partir du 15 courant.

Les porteurs d'actions ordinaires devront a cet effet presenter leurs titres: a Alexandrie au siege de la Societe; a Londres a L'Anglo Foreign Banking Co.Ld.2 Bishopsgate Street Within, E.C. a Bruxelles a la Societe Belge de Credit Industriel & Commercial et de Depots60 Rue Royale. pour les faire estampiller et recevoir les Actions Privilegiees auxquelles ils ont droit a raison d'une Action Privilegiee pour une Action or- dinaire.
L'Administrateur-Directeur, (Signe) E. W. P. FOSTER. Alexandrie, le 8 Juillet 1907. 3059-4-A-2

div.head: The Egyptian Delta Light Railways, LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street. in the City of London, on Tuesday, 23rd July, 1907, at 3 o'clock p.m. precisely, for the purpose of receiving the Directors' Report and Balance Sheet for the year ended 31st March, 1907, electing Directors in the place of the three retiring by rotation, appointing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their remuneration, declaring a Dividend, and transacting the Ordinary. General Business of the Company, and also for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit passing, with or without modification, the following Resolu- tion then intended to be proposed, that is to say :-
RESOLUTION.

"That the Board of Directors be authorised to enter into an Agreement on behalf of the Company with the Egyptian Government modifying the Deed of Concession for the Helouan Railways and Schedule of Condi- tions dated 30th April, 1888, in the form now submitted to the Meeting and signed by the Chairman for the purpose of identification subject to any modifications or alterations to such Agreement as the Board may deem desrable."
By Order of the Board, F.J. HORNE, Secretary.
The agreement above referred to may be inspected at the Office of the Company at any time during business hours prior to the Meeting.
211, GRESHAM HOUSE, OLD BROAD STREET, LONDON, E.C. 4th July, 1907.

N.B.-Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the General Meeting of the Company, they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants either in London at the Registered Office of the Company or at any London Clearing House Bank, or at the London Office of the National Bank of Egypt, the Bank of Egypt, the Anglo- Egyptian Bank, Limited, Credit Lyonnais, or the Imperial Ottoman Bank, two clear days before the date of the Meeting, i.e., not later than the 20th July, or in Egypt with any of the last-mentioned Banks ten clear days before the date of the Meeting, i.e., not later than 12th July, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held. Certificates of Deposit to be signed by the depositees in exchange for the Share Warrants so lodged, which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting, may be obtained upon applica- tion to the London or Cairo Offices of the Company. Should Shareholders wish to vote by proxy the Certificate of Deposit must be sent in to Company's Office attached to the Proxy Form at least 48 hours before the General Meeting is held.
Dividend Warrants will be issued on the 20th July 1907. 30607-4-2

Les personnes qui adressent des demandes a la Societe, sont priees de joindre un timbre pour la reponse.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
VOYAGES D'ETE A PRIX REDUITS.
div.p: La Khedivial Mail Line mettra en vente a ses Agences d'Alexandrie, du Caire et de Port Said des billets speciaux d'aller et retour qui permettront aux personnes desireuses de se rafraichir par un petit voyage en GRECE, a SMYRNE, METELIN, CONSTANTINOPLE ou en SYRIE, de le faire a un taux reduit pendant les mois de JUILLET et AOUT.
La nourriture pendant deux jours de qua- rantaine est comprise dans ces prix.

Des prix reduits seront accordes aux passa- gers par plusieurs hotels a Constantinople, comme aussi au Phalere, Athenes, etc., et si les passagers en premiere classe desirent rester a bord a Constantinople et retourner par le meme vapeur, ils auront la faculte de le faire en payant Fcs. 10 par jour pour leur nour- riture.

Pour la SYRIE on emettra egalement des billets speciaux au prix du voyage simple pour le voyage de l'aller et de retour. Le prix du voyage d'Alexandrie a Beyrouth et retour sera donc L.E. 3.500 par personne en premiere classe et L.E. 2.600 en deuxieme classe.
CONDITIONS.
Les billets pour ces voyages ne pourront etre obtenus qu'aux Agences de la Compagnie a Alexandrie, Port Said et au Caire (Bonded Stores).
Les billets seront strictement personnels et aucune autre reduction ne sera accordee.

La duree de la validite des billets est de trois semaines a compter de l'arrivee au port de destination. Leur validite ne peut pas etre prolongee sauf contre paiement de la difference entre le prix de ces billets et celui des billets ordinaires.
Les passagers munis de ces billets n'auront pas la faculte de s'arreter dans les ports inter- mediaires.
Alexandrie, le 14 juin 1907. 30586-14-5

div.head: Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
NOTICE.
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways Administra- tion has the honour to inform the public that tenders will be received up to noon on the 5th October 1907 for the supply of timber during the year 1908 in accordance with the list and detailed conditions which may be obtained, against payment of 100 millemes, at the Admin- istration's General Stores at Boulac, and at the Office of the Inspector of Stores at Gabbary (Alexandria).

The tenderer must lodge beforehand as a pro- visional deposit, the sum of L.E. 100. After acceptance of his tender, he will lodge a final guarantee by increasing the provisional deposit so as to make up an amount equal to 10% of his accepted offer.

Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of 30 milliemes and the receipt for the provisional deposit and be addressed by registered post to. "The General Manager, Egyptian State Railways, Cairo"
and in two envelopes, the inner one bearing the following inscription:-
"Tender for timber supply".
The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any tender, and reserves to itself the right of dividing the contract.
NOTICE.

The Administration has the honour to in- form the public that tenders will be received up to nooon on the 1st October 1907 for the supply of 310,000 (Three hundred and ten thousand) Metrical Tons of Welsh Coal re- quired during the year 1908 in accordance with the specification and General Conditions, copy of which can be obtained against payment of 100 milliemes at the Railway Central Stores at Boulac (Cairo) and at Gabbary (Alexandria).

Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of 30 milliemes and be addressed by registered post to "The General Manager Egyptian State Railways Cairo" and in double envelopes, the inner bearing the following inscription:-
"Tender for Coal".
The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any tender and reserves to itself the right of dividing the contract.
Cairo, 4th July 1907 30594-2-1

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu-au 5 octobre 1907 a midi au plus tard, des offres pour la fourniture des bois dont elle a besoin pendant l'annee 1908 suivant la liste et les conditions du Cahier des Charges dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire au Burean Central des Magasins Generaux a Boulac (Caire) et au bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins a Gabbary (Alexandrie), contre paiement de 100 millie- mes.

Toute personne desirant prendre part a cette adjudication devra verser, an prealable, a la Caisse de l'Administration une somme de L.Eg. 100 (Cent Livres Egyptiennes) a titre de cautionnement provisoire. Le soumission- naire declare adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a conccurence du dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agreee.

Les offres devront etre accompagnees d'une feuille de papier timbre de trente milliemes ainsi que du recu du versement du cautionne- ment provisoire susvise. Elles seront adressees par la poste sous pli recommande a Monsieur le Directeur General des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Caire, et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante: "Offre pour Fourniture de Bois".
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter l'offre la plus basse, ni a donner suite aux son- issions presentees, et elle se reserve le droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 1er Juillet 1907. 30578-2-1
AVIS

L'Administration a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 1er Octobre 1907, a midi, des offres pour la fourniture de 310,000 (Trois cent dix mille) tonnes Metriques de Charbon Welsh pendant l'annee 1908 selon les conditions du Cahier des Charges dont on peut obtenir un exem- plaire au Bureau Central du SErvice des Maga- sins a Boulac (Caire) et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) contre paiement de cent milliemes.

Les offres devront etre accompagnees d'une feuille de papier timbre de 30 Milliemes. Elles seront adressees par la poste sous pli recom- mande a :- Monsieur le Directeur General Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Le Caire. et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante.- "Offre pour Charbon."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter l'offre la plus basse, ni a donner suite aux sou- missions presentees. Elle se reserve le droit de diviser le contrat.
Le Caire, le 4 Juillet 1907. 30593-2-1

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement
div.p: OF THE
"Egyptian Gazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust- ive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton need, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt- for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.

div.head: MAKE YOUR OWN BRICKS AND SAVE TRANSPORT COSTS.
The "PROGRESS" Hand-power Brick Press.
div.p: Two men and a boy can make and stack from 5,000 to 7,000 bricks a day, after a little practice.
Pressure 12 to 15 tons per brick. Two bricks made by each stroke of the lever.
Especially suitable for making green bricks from semi-dry clay or other soil. We will report on suitability of soil if samples are submitted to us.
The press is packed for shipment fitted together.
It can be used immediately you get it. No expert fitting required. Very strongly built. Cannot get out of order. Most of the wearing parts reversible. Gross weight-packed in one case-9 cwt.
